channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Israel-Hamas War: Israel Says It Has Isolated Gaza City After ‘Large’ Attack
item.description: A military spokesman said Israel had “completed our encirclement,” while the U.S. secretary of state warned Iran against widening the conflict. Gazan health officials said the death toll there had exceeded 10,000.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli airstrikes on Gaza City on Sunday.

item.title: Five Wounded as Russian Missiles Strike Odesa, Damaging an Art Museum
item.description: In another setback, Ukraine said 19 soldiers had been killed in a strike on a medals ceremony last week. Unusually, the ceremony had been held in the open, rather than a protected space.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Clearing debris on Monday after an overnight missile strike near an art museum in Odesa, Ukraine.

item.title: As Gaza Hospitals Collapse, Medical Workers Face the Hardest Choices
item.description: Doctors say they are performing surgeries without anesthesia after weeks of Israeli bombings and siege left severe shortages of medicine, water, food and fuel. “We choose who gets ventilation by deciding who has the best chance of survival,” one doctor said.
item.dc:creator: Ameera Harouda, Maria Abi-Habib and Abu Bakr Bashir
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Medics treating a wounded Palestinian man on the floor of the Al Aqsa Martyrs hospital in Deir Al Balah, central Gaza Strip, on Sunday.

item.title: Imprisoned Nobel Winner and Iranian Rights Activist Begins a Hunger Strike
item.description: Narges Mohammadi is protesting the prison’s denial of hospital treatment for her heart condition, her family said.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Cassandra Vinograd
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Nobel laureate Narges Mohammadi is serving a 10-year sentence in Iran’s Evin prison. “We are extremely worried,” her husband, Taghi Rahmani said. “Her life is in danger.”

item.title: Ukraine’s Secret Plan to Save a City Trapped in Purgatory
item.description: Since Russian troops were pushed out of the city of Kherson, they have bombed it relentlessly. Closely held river operations could change that.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Oleksandr Naselenko and Emile Ducke
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: A man carrying water from a distribution point walks past a crater left by an air bomb that struck Kherson, last month.

item.title: Afghanistan Wins Big in Cricket’s World Cup
item.description: Afghanistan’s cricket team has won big games and many fans in an international competition, in a stark contrast to the pariah status of its government.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Atul Loke
item.media:description: Rahmanullah Gurbaz, an Afghan player, celebrating the moment his team notched a comprehensive victory against Sri Lanka last month in the Cricket World Cup.

item.title: Pope Francis Chose Not to Read Speech Due to Cold, Vatican Says
item.description: The pope, 86, who has had a number of medical scares in recent years, met Monday with European rabbis. The Vatican stressed his illness was nothing serious.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani and Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Vatican media, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: “I am not feeling well, and so I prefer not to read the speech but give you a copy so you may have it,” the pope said, meeting at the Vatican with European rabbis.

item.title: Called to Serve, Israeli Reservists Wait to Deploy
item.description: Facing a military campaign with no end in sight, tens of thousands of soldiers in Israel find themselves in a holding pattern.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Adam Sella
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Andrew Silberman, an Israeli Army reservist, guarding an outpost last month near Tekoa, a settlement in the West Bank.

item.title: Earthquake in Nepal Renews Fears on Preparations for a Bigger One
item.description: The Himalayan country is far behind in enforcing construction codes despite sitting on the fault lines of two major tectonic plates, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Bhadra Sharma and Mujib Mashal
item.media:description: In the Rukum district of northwestern Nepal on Sunday. The earthquake that struck the region on Friday destroyed or damaged at least 5,000 homes, officials estimate.

item.title: French Nuns and Climate Activists Square Off Over Plans for a Megachurch
item.description: A yearslong standoff over an enormous church complex in a natural park recently broke out in clashes, when the nuns gave chase.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola

item.title: Deadlocked War Tests Ukrainian Morale
item.description: Pessimism over prospects for a quick victory is increasing, and the spirit that infused the first days of the conflict is starting to fade, polls find.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Local residents gathering outside a damaged building in Avdiivka, Ukraine. Polls show that opposition to a negotiated settlement with Russia has dropped for the first time since the invasion.

item.title: The New Enemies of Argentina’s Far Right: Taylor Swift and BTS Fans
item.description: Javier Milei wants to be Argentina’s next president. But first he must get around legions of angry Taylor Swift and BTS fans.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Alcoba
item.media:credit: Anita Pouchard Serra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Macarena, 29, a member of a group calling on fans of Taylor Swift to vote against the Argentine presidential candidate Javier Milei. She declined to give her full name because she said the group had been threatened.

item.title: Dream Job or Arranged Marriage? An Indian Woman Ponders What’s Next.
item.description: She had dreams of a prestigious government career. Her family wanted an engagement she couldn’t refuse.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub, Emily Schmall, Shalini Venugopal Bhagat and Andrea Bruce
item.media:credit: Andrea Bruce for The New York Times

item.title: Investigators Head to Antarctica Research Base After Sexual Violence Claims
item.description: The National Science Foundation watchdog is sending agents to a U.S. research base in Antarctica after a 2022 report raised concerns about sexual misconduct.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:credit: U.S. National Science Foundation, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Members of the U.S. Antarctic Program said that sexual assault, sexual harassment and stalking were problems in the program, a 2022 National Science Foundation report found.

item.title: Blinken Warns Iran Against Widening the Israel-Hamas Conflict
item.description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken warned Iran during a weekend of diplomacy in the Middle East. The U.S. military posted a photo of one of its submarines in the region.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Rosenberg and Adam Entous
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken boarding his aircraft in Baghdad on Sunday, after meeting with Prime Minister Mohammed Shia al-Sudani of Iraq.

item.title: ‘Britain’s Loneliest Sheep’ Is Rescued From Scottish Cliff
item.description: Fiona was rescued from the bottom of a Scottish cliff on Saturday and was brought to a farm, though some animal rights activists are concerned about her new home.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: A sheep named Fiona was rescued on Saturday after spending at least two years at the bottom of a Scottish cliff.

item.title: Radio Journalist, ‘DJ Johnny Walker,’ Fatally Shot During Live Broadcast in the Philippines
item.description: A gunman shot and killed Juan Jumalon, known to his followers as D.J. Johnny Walker, while he was livestreaming his radio show on Facebook.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Calamba Municipal Police Station, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A police officer checked the room where a journalist, Juan Jumalon, was fatally shot during a live broadcast at his home in the southwest Philippines on Sunday.

item.title: Jordan Drops Medical Aid to Its Field Hospital in Gaza
item.description: It appeared to be the first time in the war that aid was dropped from a plane. Israel’s siege of Gaza has put some hospitals out of service.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek
item.media:description: A Jordanian military plane delivered humanitarian aid for Gaza via Egypt last month.

item.title: Antisemitic and Islamophobic Incidents Rise in Australia Since Start of Israel-Hamas War
item.description: Tensions between religious groups in Australia have risen since the start of the Israel-Hamas war.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Posters, towels and flip-flops intended to raise awareness of the hostages in Gaza were displayed by members of the Australian Jewish community at Bondi Beach in Sydney last week.

item.title: Janet Yellen, U.S. Treasury Secretary, Will Meet With Chinese Counterpart
item.description: The high-level meetings in San Francisco will lay the groundwork for talks between President Biden and China’s top leader, Xi Jinping.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: The talks later this week in San Francisco between Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen and Vice Premier He Lifeng of China follow Ms. Yellen’s meeting with Mr. He in Beijing in July.

item.title: Ending TB Is Within Reach — So Why Are Millions Still Dying?
item.description: Tuberculosis has passed Covid as the top infectious disease killer, despite new medicines and better diagnostic tools.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen and Natalija Gormalova
item.media:credit: Natalija Gormalova for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gifty Gyann, who was diagnosed with tuberculosis in June, was weighed at the Kaneshie Polyclinic in Accra, Ghana.

item.title: Monday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Smoke rises from Israeli airstrikes in northern Gaza on Sunday.

item.title: Blinken Meets With Palestinian and Iraqi Leaders in Bid to Contain Gaza War
item.description: The U.S. secretary of state made two unannounced visits on Sunday, the first to the Israeli-occupied West Bank and the second to Baghdad.
item.dc:creator: Adam Entous
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken meeting with President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority in the West Bank city of Ramallah on Sunday.

item.title: U.S. Officials Fear American Guns Ordered by Israel Could Fuel West Bank Violence
item.description: Israel wants 24,000 assault rifles. Itamar Ben-Gvir, a far-right minister overseeing the police, has given rifles to civilians and is forming “security squads.”
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: “Guns in the right hands save lives!” said Israel’s minister for national security, Itamar Ben-Gvir, center.

item.title: Monday Briefing: Antony Blinken Visits the Middle East
item.description: Plus the rise of space junk.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony Blinken, center right, in Baghdad yesterday.

item.title: Chance Encounter Leads to Arrest in Haiti President Assassination Case
item.description: A top Haitian police official was grocery shopping when he recognized another customer: a man wanted for questioning in the assassination of President Jovenel Moïse.
item.dc:creator: David C. Adams
item.media:description: An artist painting a mural of President Jovenel Moïse of Haiti more than two years after Mr. Moïse was assassinated. The Haitian authorities have arrested a former military officer in connection with the case.

item.title: C.I.A. Director Visits Israel and the Middle East Amid Israel-Hamas War
item.description: William J. Burns’s visit comes as the United States tries to prod Israel to pursue a more targeted approach to attacking Hamas, allow pauses in the fighting and do more to avoid civilian casualties.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Michael A. McCoy for The New York Times
item.media:description: William J. Burns, the C.I.A. director, is one of the Biden administration’s most trusted voices on Middle East issues.

item.title: Russian Strike on Soldiers at Ceremony Was a Crime, Zelensky Says
item.description: Troops were killed as they gathered in a southern village for a military commemoration, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Maria Varenikova
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Soldiers in Ukraine’s Zaporizhzhia region last year. It is highly unusual for the militaries of either Russia or Ukraine to divulge their own casualties.

item.title: Explosion Gazans Say Was Airstrike Leaves Many Casualties in Dense Neighborhood
item.description: Dozens were taken to nearby Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital, where a photographer for The New York Times saw the injured crowding the hallways and the lifeless being prepared for burial.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek and Samar Abu Elouf
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency

item.title: Netanyahu Suspends Israeli Minister Who Said Dropping a Nuclear Bomb on Gaza Was an Option
item.description: The prime minister’s swift move appeared to reflect his concerns with his waning popularity among voters, and with international criticism of Israel’s attacks on Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel suspended a far-right minister, Amichay Eliyahu, from his government on Sunday.

item.title: Israel Quietly Pushed for Egypt to Admit Large Numbers of Gazans
item.description: The Israeli government has not publicly called for large numbers of Gazans to move to Egypt. But in private, diplomats say, it has pushed for just that — augmenting Palestinian fears of a permanent expulsion.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Many people have headed to the Rafah border crossing, which connects Gaza with Egypt, in hopes of fleeing the strip.

item.title: Hamas Hostages Include Thai Farm Workers. Their Families Want Answers.
item.description: Dozens of farm workers from Thailand were kidnapped or killed in the raids on Israel, and relatives want answers. “We have nothing to do with their war,” one said.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech, Muktita Suhartono and Ryn Jirenuwat
item.media:credit: Lauren DeCicca for The New York Times
item.media:description: Watsana Yojampa and Pornchai Angkaew, the parents of Anucha Angkaew. Mr. Anucha was among a group of Thai hostages whose photos were released on social media.

item.title: Tens of thousands rallied in the U.S. in support of Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Rachel Bujalski for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pro-Palestinian protesters in front of San Francisco’s City Hall on Saturday.

item.title: Armed Standoff at Hamburg Airport Ends Peacefully After Nearly 18 Hours
item.description: The police arrested a man who had driven with his 4-year-old daughter onto the tarmac, shutting down flights. They said the child appeared unharmed.
item.dc:creator: Orlando Mayorquin
item.media:description: Emergency and police vehicles at the scene of a security breach at the Hamburg Airport on Saturday.

item.title: Blinken Meets Arab Ministers in Bid to Calm Outrage Over Israel Airstrikes
item.description: A missile attack on an ambulance convoy has drawn severe criticism, including from the U.N., but Israel says it was transporting Hamas fighters.
item.dc:creator: Adam Entous and Thomas Fuller
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: Searching through the rubble of a destroyed building after an Israeli airstrike in Khan Yunis, in the southern Gaza Strip, on Friday.

item.title: U.S. Outlines Steps to Israel to Reduce Civilian Deaths
item.description: The measures include using smaller bombs against Hamas, U.S. officials said.
item.dc:creator: Adam Entous, Eric Schmitt and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said Friday during a visit to Israel that he had spoken to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu about “concrete steps” that the United States believes Israel could and should take to minimize civilian deaths.

item.title: Zelensky Rebuke of General Signals Rift in Ukrainian Leadership
item.description: The presidential office said Gen. Valery Zaluzhny’s declaration that the war is at a stalemate was helpful to the Russians.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Maria Varenikova and Constant Méheut
item.media:description: A soldier of the 63rd Mechanized Brigade in a contested frontline area near Kreminna, in the Donetsk region of eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Militants Attack Air Base in Pakistan
item.description: Though it was repelled, the incident is part of a worrying trend of increased assaults on military targets and a rise in extremist violence more generally.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood
item.media:description: In Pakistan near the border with Afghanistan. Tensions have been rising between the two countries since the Taliban returned to power two years ago.

item.title: Rothko, in Pain and Glory
item.description: An illuminating new museum retrospective. Plus, a new podcast for kids and the latest from the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: Lyna Bentahar

item.title: Remembering Riopelle, the First Canadian Modern Artist Recognized by the World
item.description: A series of events marking the centennial of the artist’s birth includes a major retrospective at the National Gallery of Canada.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Opening night of the National Gallery of Canada’s Riopelle retrospective.

item.title: How Long Will Divorce Remain Illegal in the Philippines?
item.description: A campaign in the Philippines that frames divorce as a basic human right is gaining momentum, despite systemic and religious barriers.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Ezra Acayan
item.media:credit: Ezra Acayan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Janet Kristine Guevarra had to save more than a year’s wages to pay for an annulment.

item.title: Rashida Tlaib Posts Video Accusing Biden of Supporting ‘Genocide’
item.description: Representative Tlaib has been on the leading edge of a group of Democrats critical of the president’s embrace of Israel, but the accusation marks an extraordinary broadside from a lawmaker of his own party.
item.dc:creator: Kayla Guo
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Representative Rashida Tlaib, a Democrat of Michigan and the only Palestinian American member of Congress, at a demonstration outside the Capitol in Washington last month.

item.title: Why China-Australia Relations Are Warming. Sort of.
item.description: Both sides have been cautious in the run-up to Prime Minister Anthony Albanese’s trip to Beijing, avoiding terms like “reset” in favor of “stabilization.”
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese of Australia being welcomed by Xiao Qian, second left, China’s ambassador to Australia, upon his arrival in Shanghai on Saturday.

item.title: Israel Used 2,000-Pound Bombs in Strike on Jabaliya, Analysis Shows
item.description: Impact craters from the Oct. 31 strike on the densely packed Gaza neighborhood are approximately 40 feet wide. Israel said it was aiming at underground Hamas targets.
item.dc:creator: Christoph Koettl, Ainara Tiefenthäler, Haley Willis and Alexander Cardia

item.title: Hamas Put Wounded Fighters on Departure Lists, Delaying Gaza Evacuations, U.S. Official Says
item.description: People holding dual, U.S. or other foreign citizenship had been unable to cross the Gaza border into Egypt for weeks.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ambulances carrying wounded people from Gaza waited to cross the Rafah border into Egypt from southern Gaza on Wednesday.

item.title: Palestinian TV Reporter and 11 Family Members Killed in Gaza
item.description: Mohammed Abu Hatab is the latest journalist to die while covering the Israel-Hamas war, which has killed more media workers than any other conflict in the area since 1992.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta

item.title: Nepal Quake Kills More Than 150
item.description: Thousands of families were left under the open sky as rescuers searched for survivors in the mountainous villages where the earthquake struck.
item.dc:creator: Bhadra Sharma
item.media:description: The aftermath of the earthquake in Nepal on Saturday.

item.title: Blinken, in Tel Aviv, Urges ‘Humanitarian Pauses’ and Protections for Gaza Civilians
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel appeared to rebuff the Biden administration’s request, saying that any cease-fire would be contingent on the release of Israeli hostages taken by Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Adam Entous and Thomas Fuller
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken met with President Isaac Herzog of Israel during his visit to Tel Aviv on Friday.

item.title: U.S. Faces Tricky Questions With African Trade Group
item.description: Tensions hung over a trade summit in Johannesburg after the Biden administration suspended four African countries that had belonged to a program aimed at promoting economic development.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon and Lynsey Chutel
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Delegates from the United States and Africa attend the African Growth and Opportunity Act summit in Johannesburg on Friday.

item.title: Explosion Near Al Shifa Hospital in Gaza Kills 13 and Injures Many Others
item.description: The Israeli military said it targeted an ambulance “being used by a Hamas terrorist cell.” At the time, Palestinians said, a convoy of ambulances was preparing to take wounded people to the Gaza border.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick and Iyad Abuheweila
item.media:description: Palestinians pulling an ambulance after a convoy was hit Friday at the entrance of Shifa Hospital in Gaza City.

item.title: David Kirke, Who Made the First Modern Bungee Jump, Dies at 78
item.description: An Oxford-educated prankster as colorful as he was daring, he accidentally helped invent a new extreme sport in the 1970s.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams

item.title: Flooding in Tuscany Leaves Six Dead
item.description: Storm Ciaran swept into Italy with torrential rains overnight, continuing its deadly push across Western Europe.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:description: People cleaning the street in Montemurlo, Italy, on Friday after heavy rains overnight.

item.title: Japan and Philippines, Wary of China, Look to Expand Military Ties
item.description: An agreement, driven by the shared view that Beijing increasingly poses a threat to the region, would give Tokyo access to bases and make it easier to conduct joint drills.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Camille Elemia
item.media:description: Prime Minister Fumio Kishida of Japan, seated, at the presidential palace in Manila on Friday, where he met with President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. of the Philippines.

item.title: Is Fluminense the Team of the Future?
item.description: A soccer revolution started with a text message, but the broader game wants proof. A win in the Copa Libertadores final on Saturday might provide it.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:description: Fluminense will face Boca Juniors in the Copa Libertadores final on Saturday.

item.title: Politics and Particulates: New Delhi Fights Against Pollution
item.description: Schools shut down and residents were told to stay indoors as the government seems unable to avert an airborne calamity with multiple culprits that descends at the onset of winter.
item.dc:creator: Alex Travelli and Hari Kumar
item.media:description: Traffic in New Delhi on Friday. Despite the attempts to mitigate the effects of the pollution, there was little immediate relief for the city’s many millions of residents.

item.title: Biden Hosts Leaders of South American Nations for an Economic Summit
item.description: One goal is to help bolster economies of countries across the region so they can better absorb the millions of migrants who are fleeing poverty, political instability and natural disasters.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Yuri Gripas for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden hosted leaders from 11 Western countries to address immigration and the economy.
